posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked: Did anyone use Roboflow this year in frc with success? Just wondering what the level of entry is, how complicated it was to train the datasets, etc. Team wants to get into machine learning more, kids want to learn.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: For training datasets, there are lots I found online (as well as one we created ) The process of creating one isn’t necessarily hard, but more tedious. After you have a trained model, you can easily put it in PhotonVision’s object detection pipeline (assuming you have an Orange Pi 5) and start detecting notes (or any objects you want).

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: I have seen a lot of public datasets relative to FRC in Roboflow, mainly gamepiece and robot detection.   Apparently there are some teams trying to train object detection models.    We (19581) used it to train tflite model for FTC .

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Hey, I’m one of the co-founders of Roboflow! We love FRC & sponsor many teams ( Contribute to the Computer Vision Community ) with increased usage. I was curating this list of FRC datasets/models ( FIRST Robotics Datasets and Pre-Trained Models ) for a while but I think it may now be a bit out of date with the most recent game. Would love help getting the best models highlighted that’d be useful for more teams to use.

Models can run on-device if you have a Jetson. One of our ML Engineers worked on FRC in high school so he has a lot more context than me; I’ll flag this thread for him to add more context.

link_counts.title: FIRST Robotics Datasets and Pre-Trained Models
Contribute to the Computer Vision Community

posts.name: Maxwell
posts.cooked: Hey everyone. I’m Maxwell, ML engineer at roboflow and 2914 alum. You can find code on our github on how to deploy vision models made with roboflow for FRC . I used the OAK camera device in the past ($149 each) which runs the models on device with only 5 watts of power and includes stereo vision for distance detection OAK-D Lite – Luxonis . On small models I was able to get around 20 fps which is enough for obstacle avoidance or targeting. You can also try our jetson deployment but note that the cheap jetsons will only get you about 7-10 fps which may not be enough for fast paced actions and you also need a camera to drive them. Heres the code for the raspberry pi that controlled the cameras (2 for this deploy) GitHub - Team2914/vision-system , and heres the corresponding Java roborio code that consumed the detections and made aiming decisions https://github.com/Team2914/RapidReact . Please fee free to @ me if you run into any issues or are looking for deployment advice.
